intro: Ophrestia radicosa var. enneaneura, commonly known as the nine-veined sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Loasaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, often hairy foliage and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils, thriving in arid and semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and have a distinct venation pattern, which is a key identifying feature. The flowers, which are usually pale blue or purple, bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
